t: Job 3
Job Speaks
After*p this, Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.
He said:
“May*pn the day of my birth perish, and*ld the night that said, ‘A boy is conceived!’
That*ln day—may it turn to darkness; may*ld God above not care about it; may*ld no light shine on it.
May*ln gloom and utter darkness claim it once more; may*ld a cloud settle over it; may*ld blackness overwhelm it.
That*ln night—may thick darkness seize it; may*ld it not be included among the days of the year nor*ld be entered in any of the months.
May*ln that night be barren; may*ld no shout of joy be heard in it.
May*ln those who curse days curse that day, those*ld who are ready to rouse Leviathan.
May*ln its morning stars become dark; may*ld it wait for daylight in vain and*ld not see the first rays of dawn,
for*ln it did not shut the doors of the womb on me to*ld hide trouble from my eyes.
“Why*pn did I not perish at birth, and*ld die as I came from the womb?
Why*ln were there knees to receive me and*ld breasts that I might be nursed?
For*ln now I would be lying down in peace; I*ld would be asleep and at rest
with*ln kings and rulers of the earth, who*ld built for themselves places now lying in ruins,
with*ln princes who had gold, who*ld filled their houses with silver.
Or*ln why was I not hidden away in the ground like a stillborn child, like*ld an infant who never saw the light of day?
There*ln the wicked cease from turmoil, and*ld there the weary are at rest.
Captives*ln also enjoy their ease; they*ld no longer hear the slave driver’s shout.
The*ln small and the great are there, and*ld the slaves are freed from their owners.
“Why*pn is light given to those in misery, and*ld life to the bitter of soul,
to*ln those who long for death that does not come, who*ld search for it more than for hidden treasure,
who*ln are filled with gladness and*ld rejoice when they reach the grave?
Why*ln is life given to a man whose*ld way is hidden, whom*ld God has hedged in?
For*ln sighing has become my daily food; my*ld groans pour out like water.
What*ln I feared has come upon me; what*ld I dreaded has happened to me.
I*ln have no peace, no quietness; I*ld have no rest, but only turmoil.”
